item.title: For Refugees on Mountain, ‘No Water, Nothing’
item.description: After fleeing from ISIS, the Yazidis, a tiny religious minority, are caught up in a larger refugee disaster occurring across Iraq, one that is hitting Kurdistan especially hard.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: An Epicurean Village Is Too Rich for Some Paris Appetites
item.description: An entrepreneur aims to transform a working-class district into a high-concept gastronomic haven, but critics foresee the rise of another bourgeoisie enclave.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Capucine Granier-Deferre for The New York Times
item.media:description: An entrepreneur has acquired about half of a neighborhood north of the Marais, a trendy part of Paris, with plans to restyle it into a fine-food district called La Jeune Rue, or Young Street.

item.title: Iraq Airstrikes May Continue for Months, Obama Says
item.description: President Obama sought to prepare Americans for an extended presence in the skies over Iraq, telling reporters that the airstrikes he ordered this week, and which continued on Saturday, could go on for months.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Shawn Nickel/United States Air Force, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Parachute riggers for the United States Army prepared water to be airdropped over Iraq.

item.title: A View From the Sea, as China Flexes Muscle
item.description: A two-and-a-half month standoff over a Chinese oil rig illustrated the long reach of China’s nautical ambitions.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fishermen in Da Nang. On a two-day trip from that port, a Vietnamese vessel encountered some 70 Chinese ships.

item.title: 500,000 Told to Evacuate as Typhoon Strikes Japan
item.description: Traffic was disrupted and hundreds of flights canceled as the country headed into an annual holiday week.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. Jets and Drones Attack Militants in Iraq, Hoping to Stop Advance
item.description: American warplanes launched airstrikes against Sunni militants in northern Iraq on Friday, destroying rebel positions around Erbil, the Kurdish capital.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN, TIM ARANGO and HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: President Obama called King Abdullah II of Jordan from the Oval Office on Friday to discuss Iraq, a day after authorizing airstrikes against militants there.

item.title: After a Major Court Victory, Gay Ugandans Stage a Parade
item.description: The parade was the first public event in support of gay rights since a Ugandan court invalidated an anti-gay law.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: McCain Says Limited U.S. Strikes on Militants in Iraq Are Not Enough
item.description: Senator John McCain said he would favor sending combat air controllers into Iraq to help identify airstrike targets and expand the operation into Syria.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN WEISMAN

item.title: Deadly Clashes With Police Erupt at Pakistan Protests
item.description: A second day of confrontations between Pakistani police and supporters of Tahir-ul Qadri, a cleric who opposes Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, left at least two people dead and several hundred injured.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and WAQAR GILLANI
item.media:description: Supporters of Muhammad Tahir-ul-Qadri, a cleric who opposes Pakistan’s prime minister, rallied in Lahore on Saturday.

item.title: Ukraine Strategy Bets on Restraint by Russia
item.description: Despite growing jitters in the West, Ukraine’s military leaders said they were making a well-calculated gamble, betting that Vladimir V. Putin of Russia felt he had too much to lose to invade.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women prepared lunch Saturday in Grabovo, near the crash site of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17.

item.title: Tracing Ebola’s Breakout to an African 2-Year-Old
item.description: The current Ebola outbreak, the largest ever, seems likely to surpass all previous known Ebola outbreaks combined, and epidemiologists predict it will take months to control.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By DENISE GRADY and SHERI FINK
item.media:description: Doctors Without Borders workers at an Ebola treatment center in Guinea in April, shortly after the virus was recognized.

item.title: News Analysis: As ISIS Militants Exert Their Control, U.S. Pursues a Military Middle Road
item.description: In carrying out limited airstrikes, the United States is trying to contain the threat posed by Islamic militants but not break their hold on northern and western Iraq.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Jonathan Ernst for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Obama talked about Iraq at the White House on Saturday. He has yet to detail a plan for rolling back ISIS’ gains.

item.title: Obama Says Iraq Airstrike Effort Could Be Long-Term
item.description: President Obama sought to prepare Americans for an extended operation to aid thousands of refugees and to drive back militants in Iraq.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:credit: Jonathan Ernst for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Obama discussed the situation in Iraq before departing for his vacation from the South Lawn of the White House on Saturday.

item.title: Israelis and Gazans Clash, but Fighting Is More Subdued
item.description: With a temporary cease-fire expired, Israel said it had struck more than 30 targets, and militants fired almost a dozen rockets from Gaza.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and FARES AKRAM

item.title: Afghan Rivals Back a Deal, Once More, for President
item.description: The two candidates reaffirmed their commitment to accept the results of an internationally monitored recount of votes regardless of who prevails.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry with Ashraf Ghani, to his right, who was ahead in preliminary results from the runoff, and Abdullah Abdullah, second from right, his opponent.

item.title: Obsessed? Bewildered? Ask Dr. Mahinder Watsa
item.description: A selection of questions and answers from the Ask the Sexpert Column in The Mumbai Mirror.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mahinder Watsa is the “Ask the Sexpert” columnist in the Mumbai Mirror.

item.title: World Briefing: South Sudan: A U.N. Warning
item.description: The United Nations Security Council on Friday called for South Sudan’s feuding political leaders to resolve a mounting crisis and threatened targeted sanctions against perpetrators of ethnic violence.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Chapman Pincher, Fleet St. Scoop Specialist, Dies at 100
item.description: Mr. Pincher was a journalist whose career was spent unearthing exclusive stories from the world of double agents and secret weapons.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Indian Border Guard Released After Brief Detention
item.description: Pakistani officials on Friday released an Indian border guard who was arrested after he accidentally crossed their de facto border in the disputed Himalayan territory of Kashmir, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: World Briefing: Lebanon: Influential Exile Returns
item.description: Former Prime Minister Saad Hariri, considered Lebanon’s most influential Sunni Muslim politician, returned unexpectedly to Lebanon on Friday after three years of self-imposed exile.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Yemen: Militants Kill 15 Soldiers
item.description: Al Qaeda militants killed 15 soldiers in southern Yemen after seizing them from a public bus on Friday, military officials and witnesses said, in what appeared to be retaliation for an army offensive.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: China Looks to High-Speed Rail to Expand Reach
item.description: For China, the strategic importance of a proposed line can barely be overstated: It would provide an alternate to the longer and increasingly contentious trip through the South China Sea.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Fear of ‘Another Benghazi’ Drove White House to Airstrikes in Iraq
item.description: Interviews with multiple officials in the Obama administration paint a portrait of a president forced by the unexpectedly rapid deterioration of security in Iraq to abandon his longstanding reluctance to use military force.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN, MARK MAZZETTI and HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Pesh merga fighters on Friday near a Kurdish checkpoint west of Erbil, a city where there were concerns that the advance of ISIS would pose a risk to Americans.

item.title: While Offering Support, Obama Warns That U.S. Won’t Be ‘Iraqi Air Force’
item.description: The president, addressing critics in both parties, asserted that the United States has a “strategic interest in pushing back” ISIS.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Obama said on Friday that Iraq’s leaders must form an inclusive government in order to pull the country together.

item.title: Differences Between Israel and U.N. Over Gaza Episodes Go Back Years
item.description: Israeli attacks on United Nations facilities are repeating a pattern that an agency board of inquiry reported in 2009. Israel says it is addressing the issues.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
